Value

Class Value

  • java.lang.Object
    • Value.Value
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    DoubleValue, FloatValue, IntegerValue, LongValue, ReferenceValue, StringValue

    public abstract class Value
extends java.lang.Object
    An object of this class' subclasses represent a value in the EVM system. Such values are stored on the stack (EVM.OperandStack) or in the activation records (EVM.Activation).

    • Field Detail

      • s_integer

        public static final int s_integer
        Denotes that the object represents an integer value.

        The EVM/JVM signature of integer values is I.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • s_reference

        public static final int s_reference
        Denotes that the object represents an object value.

        The EVM/JVM signature of object values is L<Class-name>;.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • s_double

        public static final int s_double
        Denotes that the object represents a double value.

        The EVM/JVM signature of double values is D.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • s_float

        public static final int s_float
        Denotes that the object represents a float value.

        The EVM/JVM signature of float values is F.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • s_long

        public static final int s_long
        Denotes that the object represents a long value.

        The EVM/JVM signature of long values is J.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • s_byte

        public static final int s_byte
        Denotes that the object represents a byte value. Values of this type cannot be stored on the operand stack. They must be promoted to integers before being pushed on the stack.

        The EVM/JVM signature of byte values is B.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • s_short

        public static final int s_short
        Denotes that the object represents a short value. Values of this type cannot be stored on the operand stack. They must be promoted to integers before being pushed on the stack.

        The EVM/JVM signature of short values is S.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • s_char

        public static final int s_char
        Denotes that the object represents a short value. Values of this type cannot be stored on the operand stack. They must be promoted to integers before being pushed on the stack.

        The EVM/JVM signature of char values is C.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • s_boolean

        public static final int s_boolean
        Denotes that the object represents a boolean value.

        The EVM/JVM signature of boolean values is Z.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • s_string

        public static final int s_string
        Denotes that the object represents a string value. The string type is atomic in Espresso, thus we treat it like an atomic value in the EVM. However, it is really a reference to an object of the class java/lang/String.

        The EVM/JVM signature of string values is Ljava/lang/String;

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Method Detail

      • makeDefaultValueFromSignature

        public static Value makeDefaultValueFromSignature(java.lang.String s)
        Creates an object of one of Value's subclasses based on the value of the parameter s. All numeric values are initialized to 0, booleans to true, chars to ' ', and string to "".

        Parameters:
        s - Possible values for this parameter are:

        s Type Initial value
        I integer 0
        D double 0.00
        F float 0.00
        Z boolean true
        J long 0
        S short 0
        C char ' '
        B byte 0
        Ljava/lang/String; string ""

        Note, object of reference type cannot be created using this method.

        Returns:
        Returns a new object of a subclass of the Value type. This object is initialized as described above.

      • makeValue

        public static Value makeValue(java.lang.Object o)
        Creates a EVM Value object based on a java object of type String, Integer, Double, Float or Long. Remember that the Integer and the integer types are different, Integer is a class where as integer is an atomic (i.e., built in) type. The same goes for Long/long, Double/double, and Float/float.
        Parameters:
        o - An object of type String, Integer, Double, Float or Long
        Returns:
        A new object of the Value type with the same value as the o parameter.

      • makeValue

        public static Value makeValue(long lv)
        Creates a value object based on a (atomic) long value.
        Parameters:
        lv - long value.
        Returns:
        LongValue object with a long value.

      • signature2Type

        public static int signature2Type(java.lang.String s)
        Converts a signature string to a type constant.
        Parameters:
        s - string representing the signature of the type
        Returns:
        integer value representing the corresponding type (as defined in Value.

      • type2String

        public java.lang.String type2String()
        Returns a value's type as a string.
        Returns:
        A string representing the type of the value.

      • toString

        public abstract java.lang.String toString()
        Abstract method for all subclasses to implement. An implementation of this method should return the value of the object as a string.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
